Award.AwardTitle: On the Automorphic Discrete Spectrum of Classical Groups: Constructions and Characterizations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns research in number theory, a branch of mathematics that has connections to many other subjects, including data security and physics. Automorphic forms, which play an important role in modern number theory, are functions with abundant symmetries. In applications, these symmetries serve as guidelines to understand the intrinsic structures of objects in our universe. In mathematics, these symmetries are common ground for many different subjects, including geometry, number theory, mathematical physics, algebra, and analysis; the modern theory of automorphic forms provides the organizing principle for further research in these areas. This research project aims to investigate basic structures of automorphic forms and to advance understanding of the discrete spectrum of automorphic forms, with potential applications to fundamental questions in number theory and arithmetic. Graduate students are involved in the project.

This research project investigates a set of fundamental questions on square integrable automorphic forms, as well as the corresponding local problems in the representations of complex, real, and p-adic groups. The goal is to understand refined structures of automorphic forms and their connections to harmonic analysis and number theory. The investigator intends to construct explicit modules for cuspidal automorphic forms. In addition, the project aims to develop the local theory, relating it to basic problems in harmonic analysis of p-adic groups. The long-term goal is to understand the general local-global-automorphic principles in the theory of automorphic forms, which reflects one of the basic principles in arithmetic and number theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Symmetry is one of the basic structures of the universe. The symmetric structures are understood by human beiing through representations of groups in Matheamtics. Automorphic forms are transcendental functions with abundant symmetric structures. The modern theory of automorphic forms has been developed under the guidance of the Langlands program, which is aimed to develop the understanding of the internal symmetric structures of automorphic forms and the relations between different realizations of such symmetric structures. The Langlands program provides a general framework to unify Geometry, Number Theory and Harmonic Analysis, and hence provides various problems and conjectures for future investigation. 
The PI, Dihua Jiang, intends to develop explicit methods to indicate the internal symmetric structures of the automorphic forms and to describe the relations between different realizations of the symmetric structures of automorphic forms. These explicit mathods has potential to make new connections between the progress in the modern theory of automorphic forms achieved in the last half century and other subjects in Mathematics and Physics. Meanwhile, the theory developed by the PI makes progress towards the better understanding of the various difficult problems and conjectures in the modern theory of automorphic forms, and also bring up new problems and conjecture for the theory. 
In addition to the achievement of the PI in his own research, the PI teaches undergraduate courses in Mathematics, supervises the undergraduate senior theses, trains graduate students and postdocs, and organizes workshops, conferences, and research programs to train graduate students and postdocs, make connection with other experts world-wide. The PI makes his own research results available though online publication, research journal publication, and presonal presentation.
